entries.meaning: (Cornwall) alley or narrow passage e.g. Tonkin's Ope

description: Representing oh pronounced with the mouth snapped closed at the end (excrescent /p/).  Compare yep, yup, nope, and welp.Alternatively, from Russian оп (op), shortened form of Greek όπα (ópa).
From Middle English ope (“open”), shortened form of open, from Old English open (“open”). More at open.

adjectives.description: ope (comparative more ope, superlative most ope)

examples: On Sunday heaven's gate stands ope.

verbs.description: ope (third-person singular simple present opes, present participle oping, simple past and past participle oped)

examples: There came into many a burgher's pate / A text which says that heaven's gate / Opes to the rich at as easy rate / As the needle's eye takes a camel in!
